history.content:
Having personal projects on your resume is nice, because it demonstrates your passion for the field, gives you a chance to learn some new skills and showcases your ability to see something through to the end

That being said, there's no reason to be "very concerned", because there are still many things you can do to help you get an internship next year.

A few things:

  • Spend some time polishing your resume - talk to your peers, organizations like HKN/UPE or the career center to make sure your resume showcases the experiences you do have well
  • Talk to, and apply to, as many companies as possible; send online applications, take out the time to speak to people at career fairs and make an impression (once you get the first interview your resume doesn't really matter as much, only how you do at those interviews)
  • Practice interview questions via resources such as Cracking the Coding Interview, Leetcode, Hackerrank, etc, and brush up on your data structures and algorithms material if you haven't already - you want to maximise your chances of doing well at an interview

If you do all those things, you will sooner or later get interviews / coding challenges / phone screens, and from then on being well prepared for interviews will definitely help you get an offer. Good luck!

Having personal projects on your resume is nice, because it demonstrates your passion for the field, gives you a chance to learn some new skills and showcases your ability to see something through to the end

That being said, there's no reason to be "very concerned", because there are still many things you can do to help you get an internship next year.

A few things:

  • Spend some time polishing your resume - talk to your peers, organizations like HKN/UPE or the career center to make sure your resume showcases the experiences you do have well
  • Talk to, and apply to, as many companies as possible; send online applications, take out the time to speak to people at career fairs and make an impression (once you get the first interview your resume doesn't really matter as much, only how you do at those interviews) (https://intern.supply/ is a very helpful site to list all the possible companies you can apply to)
  • Practice interview questions via resources such as Cracking the Coding Interview, Leetcode, Hackerrank, etc, and brush up on your data structures and algorithms material if you haven't already - you want to maximise your chances of doing well at an interview

If you do all those things, you will sooner or later get interviews / coding challenges / phone screens, and from then on being well prepared for interviews will definitely help you get an offer. Good luck!

children.subject: So being a junior will certainly help you get interviews to some degree; not sure about how your graduation semester impacts getting interviews though, might want to ask someone who has been in a similar position for more information on that.
Thanks! One more question: do you think that just the fact that I’m a junior and will be graduating the semester after next summer will help me a good amount in getting interviews?
also make sure to get in touch with any people you know at potential employers- working the network is an important step!

history.content:
Hello,

I'm a rising junior LSCS major who's planning on graduating in Fall 2019. I have no internship experience and worked on a personal project (although I didn't come that close to finishing it) last summer. I'm currently taking CS 61C, and due to its difficulty and fast pace I haven't had any time to work on a project this summer. I'm planning on applying for summer 2019 internships, but I'm worried that my lack of project and internship experience, despite my pretty good GPA, will cause me to not get much attention from companies (as was the case for summer 2018 internships). For people who've been in this boat before and know people who've been in this position, should I be very concerned about my internship prospects and, if so, what can I do to improve my chances of getting an internship? I feel that it would be difficult to make a project in the fall because I'm taking 162.

Thanks!
history.subject: Impact of Having a Lack of Personal Projects
